that	O	O

and	O	O

:	O	O

The	O	O
management	O	O
of	O	O
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
Abstract	O	O
The	O	O
incidence	O	O
of	O	O
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
is	O	O
increasing	O	O
.	O	O

As	B	B
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
is	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
adverse	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
outcomes	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
has	O	O
long	O	O
-	O	O
term	O	O
implications	O	O
for	O	O
both	O	O
mother	O	O
and	O	O
child	O	O
,	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
important	O	O
that	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
recognized	O	O
and	O	O
appropriately	O	O
managed	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
review	O	O
will	O	O
examine	O	O
the	O	O
pharmacological	O	O
options	O	O
for	O	O
the	O	O
management	O	O
of	O	O
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
,	O	O
as	O	O
well	O	O
as	O	O
the	O	O
evidence	O	O
for	O	O
blood	O	O
glucose	O	O
monitoring	O	O
,	O	O
dietary	O	O
and	O	O
exercise	O	O
therapy	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
medical	O	O
management	O	O
of	O	O
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
is	O	O
still	O	O
evolving	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
recent	O	O
randomized	O	O
controlled	O	O
trials	O	O
have	O	O
added	O	O
considerably	O	O
to	O	O
our	O	O
knowledge	O	O
in	O	O
this	O	O
area	O	O
.	O	O

As	B	B
insulin	O	O
therapy	O	O
is	O	O
effective	O	O
and	O	O
safe	O	O
,	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
considered	O	O
the	O	O
gold	O	O
standard	O	O
of	O	O
pharmacotherapy	O	O
for	O	O
gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
,	O	O
against	O	O
which	O	O
other	O	O
treatments	O	O
have	O	O
been	O	O
compared	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
current	O	O
experience	O	O
is	O	O
that	O	O
the	O	O
short	O	O
acting	O	O
insulin	O	O
analogs	O	O
lispro	O	O
and	O	O
aspart	O	O
are	O	O
safe	O	O
,	O	O
but	O	O
there	O	O
are	O	O
only	O	O
limited	O	O
data	O	O
to	O	O
support	O	O
the	O	O
use	O	O
of	O	O
long	O	O
acting	O	O
insulin	O	O
analogs	O	O
.	O	O

There	O	O
are	O	O
randomized	O	O
controlled	O	O
trials	O	O
which	O	O
have	O	O
demonstrated	O	O
efficacy	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
oral	O	O
agents	O	O
glyburide	O	O
and	O	O
metformin	O	O
.	O	O

Whilst	O	O
short	O	O
-	O	O
term	O	O
data	O	O
have	O	O
not	O	O
demonstrated	O	O
adverse	O	O
effects	O	O
of	O	O
glyburide	O	O
and	O	O
metformin	O	O
on	O	O
the	O	O
fetus	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
they	O	O
are	O	O
increasingly	O	O
being	O	O
used	O	O
in	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
,	O	O
there	O	O
remain	O	O
long	O	O
-	O	O
term	O	O
concerns	O	O
regarding	O	O
their	O	O
potential	O	O
for	O	O
harm	O	O
.	O	O

Background	O	O
Gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
(	O	O
GDM	O	O
)	O	O
is	O	O
defined	O	O
as	O	O
“	O	O
carbohydrate	O	O
intolerance	O	O
with	O	O
onset	O	O
or	O	O
first	O	O
recognition	O	O
during	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
”.	O	O
1Large	O	O
studies	O	O
have	O	O
found	O	O
that	O	O
GDM	O	O
occurs	O	O
in	O	O
2	O	O
.	O	O
2	O	O
%–	O	O
8	O	O
.	O	O

encouraged	O	O
.	O	O

Summary	O	O
and	O	O
conclusions	O	O
Gestational	O	O
diabetes	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
common	O	O
disorder	O	O
which	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
majority	O	O
of	O	O
cases	O	O
,	O	O
should	O	O
initially	O	O
be	O	O
managed	O	O
by	O	O
dietary	O	O
measures	O	O
.	O	O

These	O	O
include	O	O
a	O	O
restriction	O	O
in	O	O
fat	O	O
and	O	O
simple	O	O
carbohydrate	O	O
intake	O	O
,	O	O
regular	O	O
distribution	O	O
of	O	O
meals	O	O
,	O	O
carbohydrate	O	O
foods	O	O
favoring	O	O
those	O	O
with	O	O
low	O	O
glycemic	O	O
index	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
caloric	O	O
restriction	O	O
for	O	O
those	O	O
who	O	O
are	O	O
obese	O	O
.	O	O

Moderate	O	O
physical	O	O
activity	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
encouraged	O	O
.	O	O

Fasting	O	O
and	O	O
post	O	O
-	O	O
prandial	O	O
glucose	O	O
testing	O	O
is	O	O
necessary	O	O
for	O	O
monitoring	O	O
and	O	O
guidance	O	O
of	O	O
therapy	O	O
.	O	O

Where	O	O
dietary	O	O
measures	O	O
are	O	O
inadequate	O	O
to	O	O
achieve	O	O
glycemic	O	O
targets	O	O
,	O	O
insulin	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
introduced	O	O
.	O	O

Insulin	O	O
is	O	O
still	O	O
the	O	O
mainstay	O	O
of	O	O
pharmacological	O	O
treatment	O	O
of	O	O
GDM	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
this	O	O
is	O	O
ideally	O	O
administered	O	O
in	O	O
a	O	O
basal	O	O
bolus	O	O
regimen	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
rapid	O	O
acting	O	O
analogs	O	O
lispro	O	O
and	O	O
aspart	O	O
are	O	O
considered	O	O
safe	O	O
,	O	O
but	O	O
the	O	O
safety	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
long	O	O
-	O	O
acting	O	O
analogs	O	O
are	O	O
yet	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
determined	O	O
.	O	O

Whilst	O	O
there	O	O
are	O	O
studies	O	O
demonstrating	O	O
short	O	O
-	O	O
term	O	O
safety	O	O
of	O	O
glyburide	O	O
and	O	O
metformin	O	O
during	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
,	O	O
I	O	O
suggest	O	O
that	O	O
they	O	O
be	O	O
reserved	O	O
for	O	O
situations	O	O
where	O	O
implementation	O	O
of	O	O
insulin	O	O
therapy	O	O
is	O	O
impractical	O	O
or	O	O
not	O	O
possible	O	O
.	O	O

After	O	O
all	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
know	O	O
that	O	O
insulin	O	O
therapy	O	O
is	O	O
safe	O	O
and	O	O
usually	O	O
effective	O	O
.	O	O

ACHOIS	O	O
has	O	O
shown	O	O
that	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
acceptable	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
majority	O	O
of	O	O
women	O	O
.	O	O

By	O	O
eschewing	O	O
insulin	O	O
,	O	O
doctors	O	O
may	O	O
actually	O	O
be	O	O
treating	O	O
their	O	O
own	O	O
perceived	O	O
fear	O	O
of	O	O
injections	O	O
,	O	O
rather	O	O
than	O	O
providing	O	O
the	O	O
best	O	O
therapy	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
patient	O	O
.	O	O

Based	O	O
on	O	O
our	O	O
current	O	O
information	O	O
,	O	O
insulin	O	O
is	O	O
still	O	O
the	O	O
best	O	O
option	O	O
,	O	O
with	O	O
the	O	O
least	O	O
potential	O	O
for	O	O
long	O	O
-	O	O
term	O	O
risk	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
mother	O	O
and	O	O
child	O	O
.	O	O

With	O	O
good	O	O
medical	O	O
and	O	O
obstetric	O	O
care	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
risks	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
minimal	O	O
.	O	O

However	O	O
,	O	O
a	O	O
woman	O	O
with	O	O
GDM	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
woman	O	O
at	O	O
high	O	O
risk	O	O
of	O	O
future	O	O
diabetes	O	O
.	O	O

Therefore	B	B
after	O	O
the	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
,	O	O
healthy	O	O
lifestyle	O	O
measures	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
encouraged	O	O
to	O	O
minimize	O	O
the	O	O
likelihood	B	B
of	O	O
developing	O	O
diabetes	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
regular	O	O
screening	O	O
for	O	O
diabetes	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
undertaken	O	O
.	O	O

KEY	O	O

POINTS	O	O
Obesity	O	O
results	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
complex	O	O
combination	O	O
of	O	O
factors	O	O
that	O	O
act	O	O
at	O	O
many	O	O
stages	O	O
throughout	O	O
a	O	O
person	O	O
'	O	O
s	O	O
life	O	O
.	O	O

Therefore	B	B
,	O	O
examining	O	O
childhood	O	O
nutrition	O	O
and	O	O
obesity	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
developmental	O	O
perspective	O	O
is	O	O
warranted	O	O
.	O	O

A	O	O
developmental	O	O
perspective	O	O
recognizes	O	O
the	O	O
cumulative	O	O
effects	O	O
of	O	O
factors	O	O
that	O	O
contribute	O	O
to	O	O
eating	O	O
behavior	O	O
and	O	O
obesity	O	O

including	O	O
biological	O	O
and	O	O

factors	O	O
that	O	O
are	O	O
relevant	O	O
at	O	O
different	O	O
stages	O	O
of	O	O
development	O	O
.	O	O

perspective	O	O
considers	B	B
family	O	O
,	O	O
school	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
community	O	O
context	O	O
.	O	O

During	O	O
gestation	O	O

risk	O	O

for	O	O

maternal	O	O

.	O	O

In	O	O

practices	O	O
,	O	O

in	O	O

considered	O	O
.	O	O

As	B	B
children	O	O
become	O	O
more	O	O
independent	O	O

for	O	O

Introduction	O	O
Obesity	O	O
results	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
combination	O	O
of	O	O
factors	O	O
that	O	O
occur	O	O
at	O	O
different	O	O
stages	O	O
during	O	O
a	O	O
person	O	O
'	O	O
s	O	O
lifetime	O	O
.	O	O

Therefore	B	B
,	O	O
childhood	O	O
nutrition	O	O
and	O	O
obesity	O	O
should	O	O
be	O	O
examined	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
developmental	O	O
perspective	O	O
.	O	O

First	O	O
,	O	O
prenatal	O	O
and	O	O

of	O	O

adulthood	O	O
(	O	O
1	O	O
).	O	O

to	I	O

2	O	O

Finally	O	O

cumulative	O	O

may	O	O
lead	B	O
to	I	O
—	O	O

—	O	O
obesity	O	O
.	O	O

nutrition	O	O
and	O	O

a	O	O

for	O	O

and	O	O

(	O	O

of	O	O

1	O	O

that	O	O

Discussion	O	O
These	O	O
data	O	O
demonstrate	O	O
that	O	O
intrauterine	O	O
,	O	O
lactational	O	O
and	O	O
post	O	O
-	O	O

of	O	O

female	O	O
rat	O	O

to	O	O

on	O	O
ovarian	O	O
function	O	O

into	O	O
adulthood	O	O
.	O	O

post	O	O
-	O	O
weaning	O	O
high	O	O
fat	O	O
diet	O	O

dams	O	O
that	O	O

,	O	O
and	O	O

calorie	O	O
restricted	O	O
offspring	O	O
this	O	O

was	O	O
relatively	O	O
small	O	O

to	O	O
that	O	O
of	O	O
early	O	O
life	O	O
nutrition	O	O
.	O	O

Maternal	O	O
undernutrition	O	O

growth	O	O
restriction	O	O
as	B	B
a	O	O

of	O	O

interpreted	B	B

undernutrition	O	O
,	O	O
in	O	O
contrast	O	O
to	O	O
postnatal	O	O
undernutrition	O	O
,	O	O
leads	O	O
to	O	O
reduced	O	O
longevity	O	O
in	O	O
mice	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
our	O	O
study	O	O
,	O	O
while	O	O
puberty	O	O
was	O	O
accelerated	O	O
in	O	O
maternal	O	O
high	O	O
fat	O	O
exposed	O	O
offspring	O	O
,	O	O
ovarian	O	O
function	O	O
was	O	O
maintained	O	O
or	O	O
enhanced	O	O
into	O	O
adult	O	O
life	O	O
.	O	O

We	O	O
speculate	O	O
that	O	O
whereas	O	O
pubertal	O	O
onset	O	O
was	O	O
accelerated	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
UNP	O	O
group	O	O
to	O	O
maintain	O	O
some	O	O
potential	O	O
for	O	O
reproduction	O	O
in	O	O
an	O	O
environment	O	O
predicted	O	O
to	O	O
have	O	O
a	O	O
higher	O	O
mortality	O	O
risk	O	O
,	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
HF	O	O
offspring	O	O
maturation	O	O
was	O	O
accelerated	O	O
to	O	O
opportunistically	O	O
enhance	O	O
fitness	O	O
.	O	O

Finally	O	O
,	O	O
while	O	O
the	O	O
use	O	O
of	O	O
rodent	O	O
models	O	O
for	O	O
reproductive	O	O
investigation	O	O
is	O	O
generally	B	B
well	O	O
accepted	O	O
,	O	O
a	O	O
number	O	O
of	O	O
differences	O	O
must	O	O
be	O	O
recognized	B	B
.	O	O

Rodents	O	O
for	O	O
instance	O	O
have	O	O
short	O	O
reproductive	O	O
cycles	O	O
closely	O	O
linked	O	O
with	O	O
circadian	O	O
rhythms	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
do	O	O
not	O	O
experience	O	O
menses	O	O
or	O	O
true	O	O
“	O	O
menopause	O	O
”	O	O
as	B	B
a	O	O
result	O	O
of	O	O
follicular	O	O
depletion	O	O
as	O	O
typically	O	O
observed	O	O
in	O	O
humans	O	O
,	O	O
although	O	O
follicular	O	O
depletion	O	O
does	O	O
occur	O	O
.	O	O

Although	O	O
we	O	O
accept	O	O
that	O	O
rodents	O	O
and	O	O
humans	O	O
may	O	O
differ	O	O
in	O	O
their	O	O
adaptive	O	O
responses	O	O
to	O	O
early	O	O
life	O	O
cues	O	O
,	O	O
there	O	O
are	O	O
many	O	O
reports	O	O
outlining	O	O
associations	O	O
between	O	O
a	O	O
suboptimal	O	O
early	O	O
life	O	O
environment	O	O
and	O	O
altered	O	O
phenotype	O	O
in	O	O
both	O	O
species	O	O
[	O	O
60	O	O
],[	O	O
61	O	O
].	O	O

Conclusions	O	O
In	O	O
summary	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
have	O	O
demonstrated	O	O
that	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
rat	O	O
,	O	O
pre	O	O
-	O	O
and	O	O
postnatal	O	O
nutritional	O	O
histories	O	O
together	O	O
influence	O	O
both	O	O
ovarian	O	O

and	O	O
the	O	O
tempo	O	O
of	O	O
reproductive	O	O
maturation	O	O
in	O	O
female	O	O
offspring	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
our	O	O
study	O	O
,	O	O
both	O	O
maternal	O	O
high	O	O
fat	O	O
nutrition	O	O
and	O	O
diminished	O	O
maternal	O	O

impacted	O	O
on	O	O
female	O	O
offspring	O	O

maturation	O	O
resulting	O	O
in	O	O
early	O	O
pubertal	O	O
onset	O	O
,	O	O
most	B	B
likely	I	I
through	O	O
two	O	O
different	O	O
,	O	O
potentially	O	O

,	O	O
pathways	O	O
.	O	O

We	O	O

that	O	O

may	O	O

to	O	O

a	O	O

fitness	O	O
.	O	O

of	O	O

Abstract	O	O
Adult	O	O
onset	O	O
glioma	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O

than	O	O

and	O	O

of	O	O
this	O	O

.	O	O

to	O	O

radiation	O	O

the	O	O
only	O	O
well	O	O
established	O	O

risk	O	O

only	O	O

small	O	O
percentage	O	O
of	O	O
cases	O	O
.	O	O

Several	O	O

have	O	O
reported	O	O

between	O	O
season	O	O
of	O	O

and	O	O

Introduction	O	O
Gliomas	O	O
are	O	O
a	O	O
heterogeneous	O	O

of	O	O

the	O	O
most	O	O

malignant	O	O
brain	O	O
tumors	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
].	O	O

ε	O	O

exacerbations	O	O
of	O	O
asthma	O	O
.	O	O

Severe	O	O
or	O	O

may	O	O

risk	O	O
of	O	O
fetal	O	O
death	O	O
,	O	O
low	O	O
birth	O	O

,	O	O

,[	O	O

14	O	O

severe	O	O
or	O	O

considered	O	O
high	O	O
-	O	O
risk	O	O

Management	O	O
of	O	O
Chronic	O	O
Asthma	O	O

The	O	O

effective	O	O
3	O	O
-	O	O

Rhinitis	O	O

Anaphylaxis	O	O
The	O	O
exact	O	O
prevalence	O	O
of	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
during	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
is	O	O
unknown	O	O
,	O	O
but	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
extremely	O	O
uncommon	O	O
[	O	O
30	O	O
].	O	O

The	O	O
fetus	O	O
seems	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
relatively	O	O
protected	O	O
from	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
perhaps	O	O
because	O	O
the	O	O
placenta	O	O
does	O	O
not	O	O
transmit	O	O
specific	O	O
IgE	O	O
antibodies	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
fetus	O	O
[	O	O
31	O	O
].	O	O

However	O	O
,	O	O
maternal	O	O
hypoxia	O	O
or	O	O
hypotension	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
may	O	O
be	O	O
catastrophic	O	O
not	O	O
only	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
mother	O	O
but	O	O
also	O	O
to	O	O
her	O	O
fetus	O	O
.	O	O

Maternal	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
fetal	O	O
distress	O	O
,	O	O
brain	O	O
injury	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
fetal	O	O
loss	O	O
(	O	O
presumably	B	B
because	O	O
of	O	O
diminished	O	O
uteroplacental	O	O
perfusion	O	O
),	O	O
as	O	O
well	O	O
as	O	O
neonatal	O	O
death	O	O
[	O	O
32	O	O
-	O	O
35	O	O
].	O	O

Any	O	O
agent	O	O
that	O	O
can	O	O
cause	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
nonpregnant	O	O
state	O	O
could	O	O
also	O	O
cause	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
susceptible	O	O
or	O	O
sensitized	O	O
pregnant	O	O
patient	O	O
.	O	O

Even	O	O
breast	O	O
-	O	O
feeding	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
in	O	O
2	O	O
postpartum	O	O
women	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
reactions	O	O
occurred	O	O
within	O	O
1	O	O
to	O	O
3	O	O
days	O	O
postpartum	O	O
and	O	O
resolved	O	O
within	O	O
1	O	O
to	O	O
2	O	O
days	O	O
.	O	O

Changing	O	O
levels	O	O
of	O	O
progesterone	O	O
and	O	O
triggering	O	O
by	O	O
nonsteroidal	O	O
anti	O	O
-	O	O
inflammatory	O	O
drugs	O	O
were	O	O
suggested	O	O
as	O	O
potential	O	O
causes	O	O
[	O	O
36	O	O
].	O	O

The	O	O
management	O	O
of	O	O
anaphylaxis	O	O
during	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
is	O	O
the	O	O
same	O	O
as	O	O
for	O	O
nonpregnant	O	O
patients	O	O
.	O	O

Of	O	O
the	O	O
routine	O	O

medications	O	O
,	O	O

and	O	O

Nonpharmacological	O	O

of	O	O

should	O	O
be	O	O
considered	O	O
only	O	O
in	O	O
individuals	O	O
with	O	O

risk	O	O
or	O	O
existing	O	O
allergy	O	O
[	O	O

,	O	O
115	O	O
].	O	O

Diet	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
Infants	O	O
As	O	O
mentioned	O	O
previously	O	O
,	O	O
for	O	O
breast	O	O
-	O	O

against	O	O

and	O	O

recent	O	O

and	O	O

not	O	O

the	O	O
rate	O	O
of	O	O

in	O	O

[	O	O
88	O	O
].	O	O

are	O	O

that	O	O

-	O	O

beyond	O	O
9	O	O
months	O	O
of	O	O
age	O	O

to	O	O
increase	O	O
the	O	O
child	O	O

for	O	O
atopic	O	O

such	O	O
as	O	O

and	O	O

as	O	O
Brazil	O	O
'	O	O
s	O	O
,	O	O
principally	O	O
in	O	O
adolescents	O	O
[	O	O
4	O	O
].	O	O

Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
is	O	O
critical	O	O
for	O	O
the	O	O
development	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
nervous	O	O
system	O	O
[	O	O
5	O	O
],[	O	O
6	O	O
]	O	O
and	O	O
immunological	O	O
functions	O	O
[	O	O
7	O	O
]	O	O
during	O	O
fetal	O	O
development	O	O
.	O	O

Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
pregnancy	O	O
is	O	O
important	O	O
to	O	O
both	O	O
maternal	O	O
skeletal	O	O
preservation	O	O
and	O	O
fetal	O	O
skeletal	O	O
formation	O	O
.	O	O

However	O	O
,	O	O
new	O	O
evidence	O	O
suggests	O	O
that	O	O
vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
could	O	O
be	O	O
vital	O	O
to	O	O
normal	O	O
fetal	O	O
development	O	O
and	O	O
that	O	O
vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
restriction	O	O
in	O	O
this	O	O
period	O	O
may	O	O
affect	O	O
chronic	O	O
disease	O	O
susceptibility	O	O
post	O	O
-	O	O
natal	O	O
life	O	O
[	O	O
8	O	O
].	O	O

Furthermore	O	O
,	O	O
recent	O	O
studies	O	O
have	O	O
shown	O	O
that	O	O
this	O	O
restriction	O	O
can	O	O
generate	O	O
“	O	O
genomic	O	O
imprinting	O	O
”	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
fetus	O	O

which	O	O
is	O	O
related	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
genesis	O	O
of	O	O
chronic	O	O
diseases	O	O
in	O	O
adulthood	O	O
[	O	O
9	O	O
].	O	O

Moreover	O	O
,	O	O
vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
is	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
premature	O	O
births	O	O
,	O	O

and	O	O
renal	O	O
dysfunction	O	O
in	O	O
adulthood	O	O

it	O	O
more	O	O
than	O	O
an	O	O
essential	O	O
fat	O	O
-	O	O
soluble	O	O
vitamin	O	O
responsible	B	B
for	O	O
calcium	O	O
metabolism	O	O
[	O	O
9	O	O
],[	O	O
10	O	O
].	O	O

development	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
kidney	O	O

a	O	O
highly	O	O
complex	O	O
process	O	O
that	O	O
requires	O	O
precise	O	O

and	O	O
apoptosis	O	O
[	O	O
11	O	O

(	O	O

of	O	O
the	O	O
glomerular	O	O
slit	O	O

'	O	O
tumor	O	O
suppressor	O	O
gene	O	O
WT1	O	O
[	O	O

Together	O	O

is	O	O
possible	O	O

should	O	O

3	O	O
million	O	O

mothers	O	O
.	O	O

Rapid	O	O
progress	O	O
is	O	O
possible	O	O
.	O	O

At	O	O

These	O	O

Introduction	O	O

linking	O	O
maternal	O	O
stress	O	O
to	O	O
fetal	O	O
development	O	O
.	O	O

of	O	O
these	O	O
polymorphisms	O	O
are	O	O
functionally	O	O
relevant	O	O
and	O	O
these	O	O
are	O	O
the	O	O
Tth111	O	O
I	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
ER22	O	O
/	O	O
23EK	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
N363S	O	O

the	O	O
—	O	O
already	O	O

—	O	O
Bcl	O	O

the	O	O

9	O	O
β	O	O
.	O	O

that	O	O

.	O	O

with	O	O

between	O	O
family	O	O
members	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
model	O	O
allows	O	O
all	O	O
data	O	O
from	O	O
incomplete	O	O
families	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
used	O	O
.	O	O

A	O	O
linear	O	O
mixed	O	O
-	O	O
model	O	O
analysis	O	O
is	O	O
adopted	O	O
.	O	O

Each	O	O
individual	O	O
has	O	O
a	O	O
family	O	O
id	O	O
and	O	O
within	O	O
a	O	O
family	O	O
individuals	O	O
are	O	O
also	O	O
numbered	O	O
according	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
group	O	O
to	O	O
which	O	O
they	O	O
belong	O	O
:	O	O
child	O	O
=	O	O
1	O	O
,	O	O
mother	O	O
=	O	O
2	O	O
,	O	O
father	O	O
=	O	O
3	O	O
,	O	O
MGM	O	O
=	O	O
4	O	O
,	O	O
maternal	O	O
grandfather	O	O
(	O	O
MGF	O	O
)=	O	O
5	O	O
,	O	O
PGM	O	O
=	O	O
6	O	O
and	O	O
PGF	O	O
=	O	O
7	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
unit	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
model	O	O
is	O	O
the	O	O
family	O	O
member	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
mixed	O	O
model	O	O
includes	O	O
group	O	O
,	O	O
age	O	O
and	O	O
group	O	O
Χ	O	O
age	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
family	O	O
member	O	O
as	O	O
fixed	O	O
effects	O	O
and	O	O
a	O	O
random	O	O
family	O	O
effect	O	O
with	O	O
an	O	O
unstructured	O	O
correlation	O	O
matrix	O	O
.	O	O

Note	O	O
:	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
case	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
child	O	O
,	O	O
age	O	O
represents	O	O
the	O	O
exact	O	O
age	O	O
when	O	O
measurements	O	O
were	O	O

.	O	O

Estimates	O	O
of	O	O
this	O	O
correlation	O	O
matrix	O	O
are	O	O

estimates	O	O

is	O	O

,	O	O

p	O	O
values	O	O
.	O	O

These	O	O
correlations	O	O

of	O	O

between	O	O

phenotypic	O	O

.	O	O

The	O	O
p	O	O
value	O	O
of	O	O

or	O	O

.	O	O

.	O	O

at	O	O

of	O	O
the	O	O

].	O	O

included	O	O
24	O	O
validated	O	O
items	O	O
on	O	O

attitudes	O	O
,	O	O

.	O	O

Generalized	O	O
estimating	O	O
equations	O	O
(	O	O
GEE	O	O
)	O	O
logistic	O	O
regression	O	O
was	O	O
used	O	O
to	O	O

,	O	O
beliefs	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
behavioral	O	O
outcomes	O	O
over	O	O
the	O	O
3	O	O
follow	O	O
-	O	O
up	O	O
periods	O	O
,	O	O

exposure	O	O
of	O	O
224	O	O
days	O	O
)	O	O
vs	O	O

intervention	O	O
exposure	O	O
.	O	O

odds	O	O
of	O	O
change	O	O
over	O	O

in	O	O

to	O	O

of	O	O
the	O	O
behavioral	O	O
outcome	O	O
variables	O	O
as	O	O
a	O	O
function	O	O
of	O	O
text4baby	O	O
text	O	O
message	O	O
exposure	O	O
through	O	O
use	O	O
of	O	O
an	O	O
interaction	O	O
term	O	O
including	O	O
program	O	O
exposure	O	O
and	O	O
progression	O	O
to	O	O
follow	O	O
-	O	O
up	O	O
measurement	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
addition	O	O
to	O	O
an	O	O
unadjusted	O	O
model	O	O
,	O	O
which	O	O

who	O	O

and	O	O
at	O	O
least	O	O
1	O	O
follow	O	O
-	O	O
up	O	O
interview	O	O
(	O	O
n	O	O
=	O	O
459	O	O
),	O	O
a	O	O
second	O	O
adjusted	O	O
model	O	O

in	O	O

Conclusion	O	O

of	O	O

.	O	O

.	O	O

of	O	O
miRNAs	O	O

GR	O	O

receptor	O	O
(	O	O

Introduction	O	O
Cathelicidin	O	O
(	O	O
Human	O	O
LL	O	O
-	O	O
37	O	O
),	O	O
activated	O	O
by	O	O
n	O	O
-	O	O
terminal	O	O
cleavage	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
propeptide	O	O
hCAP18	O	O
,	O	O
serves	O	O
as	O	O
a	O	O
cytokine	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
immune	O	O
system	O	O
as	O	O
well	O	O
as	O	O
an	O	O
antimicrobial	O	O
peptide	O	O
with	O	O
its	O	O
ability	O	O
to	O	O
form	O	O
an	O	O
α	O	O
-	O	O
helix	O	O
in	O	O
aqueous	O	O
solution	O	O
that	O	O
disrupts	O	O
the	O	O
lipid	O	O
membranes	O	O
of	O	O
invading	O	O
organisms	O	O
and	O	O
results	O	O
in	O	O
their	O	O
destruction	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
–	O	O
4	O	O
].	O	O

Primarily	O	O
utilized	O	O
by	O	O
monocytes	O	O

,	O	O
mucosal	O	O
epithelial	O	O
cells	O	O

and	O	O

of	O	O

with	O	O
other	O	O
cytokines	O	O
and	O	O
signal	O	O
molecules	O	O
as	O	O
a	O	O
first	O	O
line	O	O
of	O	O
defense	O	O
[	O	O
5	O	O
].	O	O

AbstractAbstract	O	O
Throughout	O	O
our	O	O
lives	O	O

.	O	O

epigenetic	O	O
change	O	O
(	O	O

.	O	O

and	O	O

regulatory	O	O

Introduction	O	O
The	O	O
belief	O	O
that	O	O
the	O	O
sequence	O	O
of	O	O
our	O	O
DNA	O	O
(	O	O
our	O	O
genome	O	O
)	O	O
is	O	O
the	O	O
sole	O	O
determinant	O	O
of	O	O
our	O	O
life	O	O
-	O	O
long	O	O
development	O	O
and	O	O
health	O	O
has	O	O
long	O	O
been	O	O
regarded	O	O
as	B	O
too	O	O
simplistic	O	O
.	O	O

Darwin	O	O
’	O	O
s	O	O
‘	O	O
On	O	O
the	O	O
Origin	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
Species	O	O
’	O	O
highlighted	O	O
the	O	O
role	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
environment	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
process	O	O
of	O	O
evolution	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
natural	O	O
selection	O	O
of	O	O
advantageous	O	O
genetic	O	O
mutations	O	O
through	O	O
environmental	O	O
pressures	O	O
(	O	O
Darwin1859	O	O
).	O	O

It	O	O
has	O	O
also	O	O
been	O	O
recognized	B	B
that	O	O
the	O	O
pace	O	O
of	O	O
such	O	O
change	O	O
is	O	O
sometimes	O	O
too	O	O
rapid	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
accounted	O	O
for	O	O
by	O	O
natural	O	O
selection	O	O
.	O	O

First	O	O
Lamarck	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
then	O	O
Waddington	O	O
,	O	O
suggested	O	O
that	O	O
alternative	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
,	O	O
now	O	O
termed	O	O
epigenetics	O	O
,	O	O
must	O	O
also	O	O
contribute	O	O
to	O	O
phenotypic	O	O
outcomes	O	O
(	O	O
Noble2006	O	O
).	O	O

Epigenetics	O	O
encompasses	O	O
the	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
that	O	O
regulate	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
without	O	O
altering	O	O
the	O	O
underlying	O	O
DNA	O	O
sequence	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
complete	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
status	O	O
of	O	O
a	O	O
cell	O	O
at	O	O
any	O	O
given	O	O
time	O	O
is	O	O
termed	O	O
the	O	O
epigenome	O	O
.	O	O

Epigenetic	O	O
programing	O	O
is	O	O
fundamental	O	O
for	O	O
normal	O	O
mammalian	O	O
development	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
provides	O	O
a	O	O
more	O	O
subtle	O	O
mechanism	O	O
by	O	O
which	O	O
the	O	O
environment	O	O
can	O	O
rapidly	O	O
alter	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
within	O	O
single	O	O
or	O	O
multiple	O	O
generations	O	O
.	O	O

It	O	O
is	O	O
the	O	O
complex	O	O
interaction	O	O
among	O	O
our	O	O
genome	O	O
,	O	O
epigenome	O	O
and	O	O
environment	O	O
that	O	O
shapes	O	O
our	O	O
development	O	O
into	O	O
unique	O	O
individuals	O	O

and	O	O
thus	B	B
influences	O	O
our	O	O
health	O	O
and	O	O
potentially	O	O
the	O	O
health	O	O
of	O	O
our	O	O
future	O	O
offspring	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
induction	O	O
of	O	O
adverse	O	O
DNA	O	O
mutations	O	O

to	O	O
disease	O	O

particularly	O	O
cancer	O	O
,	O	O
is	O	O
well	B	B
established	I	I
and	O	O
recognized	B	B
by	O	O
regulatory	O	O
bodies	O	O
worldwide	O	O
.	O	O

As	O	O

and	O	O

We	O	O

both	O	O

PubMed	O	O

in	O	O
Supplementary	O	O
Table	O	O
1	O	O

(	O	O

,	O	O

,	O	O

and	O	O

adverse	O	O
effects	O	O
(	O	O

,	O	O

,	O	O

changes	O	O
,	O	O
reproductive	O	O

other	O	O

abnormalities	O	O
(	O	O

,	O	O

and	O	O

and	O	O
are	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
(	O	O
histone	O	O
modifications	O	O
,	O	O

,	O	O

(	O	O
ncRNAs	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
other	O	O
epigenetic	O	O

(	O	O
DNA	O	O
/	O	O

binding	O	O
and	O	O
modifying	O	O
proteins	O	O
)).	O	O

Relevant	O	O
papers	O	O
were	O	O
selected	O	O
based	O	O
on	O	O
the	O	O
inclusion	O	O

Epigenetic	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
Histones	O	O
are	O	O
a	O	O
family	O	O
of	O	O
highly	O	O
conserved	O	O
,	O	O
small	O	O
,	O	O
basic	O	O
(	O	O
positively	O	O
charged	O	O
)	O	O
proteins	O	O
around	O	O
which	O	O
(	O	O
negatively	O	O
charged	O	O
)	O	O
DNA	O	O
winds	O	O
to	O	O
form	O	O
nucleosomes	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
main	O	O
structural	O	O
units	O	O
of	O	O
chromatin	O	O
(	O	O
the	O	O
protein	O	O
-	O	O
DNA	O	O
complex	O	O
)	O	O
that	O	O
enable	O	O
DNA	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
packaged	O	O
into	O	O
the	O	O
nucleus	O	O
(	O	O
Kornberg	O	O
&	O	O
Lorch1999	O	O
).	O	O

Both	O	O
the	O	O
tails	O	O
and	O	O
globular	O	O
domains	O	O
of	O	O
histones	O	O
can	O	O
undergo	O	O
multiple	O	O
posttranslational	O	O
modifications	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
acetylation	O	O
,	O	O
methylation	O	O
,	O	O
phosphorylation	O	O
,	O	O
ADP	O	O
ribosylation	O	O
,	O	O
ubiquitination	O	O
and	O	O
sumoylation	O	O
,	O	O
giving	O	O
rise	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
so	O	O
-	O	O
called	O	O
histone	O	O
code	O	O
(	O	O
Strahl	O	O
&	O	O
Allis2000	O	O
;	O	O
Turner2000	O	O
;	O	O
Jenuwein	O	O
&	O	O
Allis2001	O	O
;	O	O
Bhaumik	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2007	O	O
;	O	O
Kouzarides2007	O	O
;	O	O
Suganuma	O	O
&	O	O
Workman2011	O	O
).	O	O

The	O	O
functional	O	O
groups	O	O
are	O	O
added	O	O
or	O	O
removed	O	O
by	O	O
a	O	O
range	O	O
of	O	O
enzymes	O	O
:	O	O
acetylases	O	O
,	O	O
methyltransferases	O	O
,	O	O
kinases	O	O
,	O	O
ADP	O	O
ribosyltransferases	O	O
,	O	O
ubiquitin	O	O
ligases	O	O
,	O	O
sumo	O	O
ligases	O	O
;	O	O
and	O	O
deacteylases	O	O
,	O	O
demethylases	O	O
,	O	O
phosphatases	O	O
,	O	O
ADP	O	O
ribosyl	O	O
hydrolases	O	O
,	O	O
deubiquitinases	O	O
,	O	O
sumo	O	O
deconjugating	O	O
enzymes	O	O
,	O	O
respectively	O	O
(	O	O
Wang	O	O
&	O	O
Dasso2009	O	O
;	O	O
Khare	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2012	O	O
).	O	O

These	O	O
modifications	O	O
alter	O	O
the	O	O
interaction	O	O
between	O	O
DNA	O	O
and	O	O
DNA	O	O
binding	O	O
proteins	O	O
(	O	O
such	O	O
as	O	O
transcription	O	O
factors	O	O
and	O	O
RNA	O	O
polymerases	O	O
)	O	O
so	O	O
that	O	O
it	O	O
is	O	O
the	O	O
overall	O	O
combined	O	O
effect	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
histone	O	O
code	O	O
that	O	O
determines	O	O
an	O	O
active	O	O
or	O	O
repressive	O	O
chromatin	O	O
structure	O	O
and	O	O
thus	O	O
regulates	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
general	O	O
,	O	O
histone	O	O
acetylation	O	O
and	O	O
demethylation	O	O
are	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
active	O	O
chromatin	O	O
(	O	O

),	O	O
while	O	O
histone	O	O
deacteylation	O	O
and	O	O
methylation	O	O
are	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
repressive	O	O
chromatin	O	O
(	O	O

).	O	O

DNA	O	O
methylation	O	O
involves	O	O
the	O	O
addition	O	O
of	O	O
a	O	O
methyl	O	O
group	O	O
,	O	O
primarily	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
C5	O	O
of	O	O
cytosine	O	O
within	O	O
cytosine	O	O
–	O	O
phosphate	O	O
–	O	O
guanine	O	O
dinucelotides	O	O
(	O	O
CpGs	O	O
)	O	O
to	O	O
produce	O	O
5	O	O
-	O	O
methylcytosine	O	O
(	O	O
5mC	O	O
).	O	O

Due	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
high	O	O
mutagenic	O	O
potential	O	O
of	O	O
5mC	O	O
to	O	O
spontaneously	O	O
deaminate	O	O
to	O	O
thymine	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
mammalian	O	O
genome	O	O
is	O	O
largely	O	O
depleted	O	O
of	O	O
CpGs	O	O
(	O	O
Bird1980	O	O
;	O	O
Bird	O	O
&	O	O
Taggart1980	O	O
),	O	O
with	O	O
the	O	O
exception	O	O
of	O	O
distinct	O	O
regions	O	O

as	O	O
CpG	O	O
islands	O	O
(	O	O
CGIs	O	O
)	O	O
(	O	O
Bird	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
1985	O	O
).	O	O

These	O	O
CpG	O	O

are	O	O
non	O	O
-	O	O
randomly	O	O
distributed	O	O
throughout	O	O
the	O	O
mammalian	O	O
genome	O	O
,	O	O
being	O	O
predominantly	O	O
associated	O	O
with	O	O
regulatory	O	O

such	O	O
as	O	O
promoters	O	O
(	O	O
Deaton	O	O
&	O	O

).	O	O

DNA	O	O
methylation	O	O
also	O	O
alters	O	O
the	O	O
interaction	O	O
between	O	O
DNA	O	O
and	O	O
DNA	O	O
binding	O	O
proteins	O	O
to	O	O
regulate	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
.	O	O

Methylation	O	O
at	O	O
CGIs	O	O
is	O	O
generally	B	B
associated	O	O
with	O	O
transcriptional	O	O
repression	O	O
,	O	O
although	O	O

within	O	O
a	O	O

can	O	O
contribute	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
actual	O	O

effect	O	O
(	O	O
Hackett	O	O
&	O	O

;	O	O
Messerschmidt	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2014	O	O
).	O	O

DNA	O	O
is	O	O

by	O	O
a	O	O
family	O	O
of	O	O

(	O	O

DNMT1	O	O
,	O	O

maintenance	O	O
DNMT	O	O
,	O	O
preferentially	O	O

.	O	O

by	O	O

.	O	O

The	O	O

of	O	O
,	O	O
DNMT3A	O	O
and	O	O
3B	O	O
.	O	O

Much	O	O
less	O	O
is	O	O

of	O	O

It	O	O
has	O	O
long	O	O

that	O	O
5mC	O	O
can	O	O
be	O	O
removed	O	O

both	O	O

(	O	O

.	O	O

Yet	O	O
,	O	O
specific	O	O
DNA	O	O

enzyme	O	O
(	O	O
s	O	O
)	O	O
in	O	O
mammals	O	O
remained	O	O

until	O	O
the	O	O
discovery	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
10	O	O
–	O	O
11	O	O
translocation	O	O
(	O	O

)	O	O
enzyme	O	O
family	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
family	O	O
,	O	O
which	O	O
can	O	O

)	O	O

5	O	O

(	O	O
5caC	O	O
)	O	O
(	O	O

et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2009	O	O
;	O	O
Ito	O	O

.	O	O
2011	O	O

research	O	O
into	O	O
indirect	O	O
active	O	O
DNA	O	O
demethylation	O	O
pathways	O	O
.	O	O

Consequently	B	B
,	O	O
a	O	O
range	O	O
of	O	O

for	O	O
the	O	O

The	O	O

The	O	O
vast	O	O

of	O	O
the	O	O
mammalian	O	O
genome	O	O
is	O	O
composed	O	O
of	O	O

called	O	O

(	O	O

.	O	O

(	O	O

).	O	O

contain	O	O
only	O	O
10	O	O
%	O	O
ncDNA	O	O
,	O	O
more	O	O
complex	O	O
fungi	O	O
and	O	O
animals	O	O
>	O	O
50	O	O
%,	O	O
rising	O	O
to	O	O
>	O	O

%	O	O
in	O	O
complex	O	O
mammals	O	O
(	O	O
including	O	O
mice	O	O
and	O	O
humans	O	O
)	O	O
(	O	O
Carey2011	O	O
).	O	O

Indeed	O	O
,	O	O
over	O	O
the	O	O
last	O	O
decade	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
previous	O	O
gene	O	O
-	O	O
centric	O	O
dogma	O	O
,	O	O
central	O	O
to	O	O

biology	O	O
,	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
shown	O	O
to	O	O
be	O	O
incorrect	O	O
.	O	O

NcDNA	O	O
is	O	O
transcribed	O	O
into	O	O
ncRNAs	O	O
,	O	O
which	O	O
play	O	O
major	O	O
roles	O	O
in	O	O
regulating	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
.	O	O

While	O	O
lncRNAs	O	O
do	O	O
this	O	O
in	O	O
a	O	O
variety	O	O
of	O	O
ways	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
chromosome	O	O
remodeling	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
transcriptional	O	O
or	O	O
post	O	O
-	O	O
transcriptional	O	O
regulation	O	O
(	O	O
Galupa	O	O
&	O	O

;	O	O
Kanduri2016	O	O
;	O	O
Taylor	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2015	O	O
),	O	O
sncRNAs	O	O
predominantly	O	O
mediate	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
at	O	O
the	O	O
post	O	O
-	O	O
transcriptional	O	O
level	O	O
(	O	O
Cook	O	O
&	O	O
Blelloch2013	O	O
;	O	O
Hale	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2014	O	O
).	O	O

In	O	O
general	O	O
,	O	O

repress	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
by	O	O
binding	O	O
to	O	O

a	O	O
sequence	O	O
-	O	O
specific	O	O
manner	O	O
and	O	O
either	O	O
inducing	O	O
their	O	O
degradation	O	O
or	O	O
inhibiting	O	O
their	O	O
translation	O	O
(	O	O

&	O	O

whereas	O	O

and	O	O

bind	O	O
to	O	O
complementary	O	O

elements	O	O
(	O	O
TEs	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
induce	O	O
their	O	O
degradation	O	O
(	O	O
Watanabe	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2006	O	O
,	O	O
2008	O	O
).	O	O

Thus	O	O
,	O	O
miRNAs	O	O
are	O	O
involved	O	O
in	O	O
fine	O	O
tuning	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
,	O	O
whilst	O	O
piRNAs	O	O
and	O	O
esiRNAs	O	O
play	O	O
a	O	O
primary	O	O
role	O	O
in	O	O
maintaining	O	O
genome	O	O
stability	O	O
.	O	O

Role	O	O
of	O	O
epigenetics	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
mammalian	O	O
life	O	O
cycle	O	O
Normal	O	O
mammalian	O	O
development	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
cyclical	O	O
series	O	O
of	O	O
events	O	O
that	O	O
enable	O	O
the	O	O
continued	O	O
production	O	O
of	O	O
multiple	O	O
generations	O	O
(	O	O
described	O	O
in	O	O
Gilbert2014	O	O
).	O	O

A	O	O
new	O	O
generation	O	O
begins	O	O
with	O	O
the	O	O
fusion	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
male	O	O
(	O	O
spermatozoa	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
female	O	O
(	O	O
oocyte	O	O
)	O	O
gametes	O	O
(	O	O
fertilization	O	O
)	O	O
to	O	O
produce	O	O
a	O	O
single	O	O
cell	O	O
(	O	O
zygote	O	O
)	O	O
containing	O	O
one	O	O
haploid	O	O
female	O	O
pronucleus	O	O
and	O	O
one	O	O
haploid	O	O
male	O	O
pronucleus	O	O
.	O	O

All	O	O
the	O	O
different	O	O
cell	O	O
types	O	O
that	O	O
comprise	O	O
the	O	O
new	O	O
individual	O	O
develop	O	O
from	O	O
this	O	O
zygote	O	O
and	O	O
so	O	O
contain	O	O
the	O	O
same	O	O
unique	O	O
genome	O	O
.	O	O

To	O	O
enable	O	O
de	O	O
-	O	O
differentiation	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
highly	O	O
specialized	O	O
mature	O	O
male	O	O
and	O	O
female	O	O
gametes	O	O
and	O	O
subsequent	O	O
generation	O	O
of	O	O
multiple	O	O
specialized	O	O
cell	O	O
types	O	O
capable	O	O
of	O	O
performing	O	O
a	O	O
wide	O	O
range	O	O
of	O	O
diverse	O	O
functions	O	O
,	O	O
these	O	O
genomes	O	O
require	O	O
differential	O	O
modifications	O	O
so	O	O
that	O	O
functionally	O	O
relevant	O	O
genes	O	O
can	O	O
be	O	O
switched	O	O
on	O	O
/	O	O
off	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
is	O	O
achieved	O	O
through	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
re	O	O
-	O	O
programing	O	O
and	O	O
programing	O	O
.	O	O

Thus	O	O
,	O	O
throughout	O	O
development	O	O

epigenetic	O	O
processes	O	O
regulate	O	O
the	O	O
expression	O	O
and	O	O

of	O	O

genes	O	O
to	O	O
drive	O	O
the	O	O
mammalian	O	O
life	O	O
cycle	O	O
.	O	O

Two	O	O
key	O	O
global	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
re	O	O
-	O	O
programing	O	O
and	O	O
programing	O	O
events	O	O
occur	O	O
,	O	O

after	O	O

early	O	O

cells	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
second	O	O
in	O	O
germ	O	O
cells	O	O
only	O	O
during	O	O
primordial	O	O
germ	O	O
cell	O	O
(	O	O

)	O	O

(	O	O

1	O	O
).	O	O

(	O	O

):	O	O

and	O	O

.	O	O

to	O	O

to	O	O

a	O	O

.	O	O

a	O	O

of	O	O

cell	O	O

to	O	O

a	O	O

individual	O	O
.	O	O

involves	O	O
global	O	O
DNA	O	O

in	O	O

‘	O	O

’	O	O
the	O	O
zygote	O	O
epigenome	O	O
and	O	O
thus	O	O
genome	O	O
.	O	O

Epigenetic	O	O
programing	O	O
via	O	O
DNA	O	O
methylation	O	O
,	O	O
histone	O	O
modifications	O	O
and	O	O

into	O	O
a	O	O
mature	O	O
adult	O	O
.	O	O

dynamics	O	O
of	O	O
this	O	O

-	O	O

and	O	O

(	O	O

et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2015	O	O
).	O	O

early	O	O

(	O	O

et	O	O

2010	O	O
;	O	O

&	O	O
Blelloch2011	O	O
).	O	O

Immediately	O	O
following	O	O

embryo	O	O
genome	O	O
requires	O	O
protection	O	O

higher	O	O
expression	O	O
of	O	O
piRNAs	O	O
and	O	O
esiRNAs	O	O

both	O	O
of	O	O
which	O	O
are	O	O
involved	O	O
in	O	O
maintaining	O	O
genome	O	O
stability	O	O
(	O	O
Watanabe	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
2006	O	O
,	O	O
2008	O	O
).	O	O

Once	O	O
transcription	O	O
within	O	O
the	O	O
embryo	O	O

is	O	O

there	O	O
is	O	O
rapid	O	O

and	O	O
differentiation	O	O
,	O	O
processes	O	O
for	O	O
which	O	O
miRNA	O	O
-	O	O
mediated	O	O
regulation	O	O
is	O	O
essential	O	O
(	O	O
Ivey	O	O
&	O	O
Srivastava2015	O	O
),	O	O
hence	O	O
increased	O	O
expression	O	O
of	O	O
miRNAs	O	O
.	O	O

It	O	O
is	O	O
worth	O	O
noting	O	O
that	O	O
some	O	O
genomic	O	O
regions	O	O
escape	O	O
this	O	O
first	O	O
global	O	O
‘	O	O
reset	O	O
’,	O	O
including	O	O
imprinted	O	O
control	O	O
regions	O	O
(	O	O
ICRs	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
most	O	O
active	O	O
TEs	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
continued	O	O
transcriptional	O	O
silencing	O	O
of	O	O
such	O	O
regions	O	O
is	O	O
essential	O	O
for	O	O
early	O	O
embryogenesis	O	O
and	O	O
genome	O	O
stability	O	O
,	O	O
respectively	O	O
.	O	O

Normal	O	O
embryo	O	O
development	O	O
requires	O	O
a	O	O
maternal	O	O
and	O	O
paternal	O	O
contribution	O	O
,	O	O
generation	O	O
of	O	O
uniparental	O	O
embryos	O	O
by	O	O
pronuclear	O	O
transplantation	O	O
results	O	O
in	O	O
developmental	O	O
failure	O	O
(	O	O
Barton	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
.	O	O
1984	O	O
;	O	O
McGrath	O	O
&	O	O
Solter1984	O	O
).	O	O

This	O	O
is	O	O
because	O	O
the	O	O
male	O	O
and	O	O
female	O	O
pronuclei	O	O
are	O	O
differentially	O	O
imprinted	O	O
;	O	O
that	O	O
is	O	O
certain	O	O
genes	O	O
carry	O	O
a	O	O
parent	O	O
-	O	O
of	O	O
-	O	O
origin	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
mark	O	O
so	O	O
that	O	O
they	O	O
are	O	O
only	O	O
expressed	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
single	O	O
parental	O	O
allele	O	O

the	O	O
correct	O	O
dosage	O	O
of	O	O
maternally	O	O
and	O	O
paternally	O	O
derived	O	O
gene	O	O

.	O	O

Epigenetic	O	O
regulation	O	O
of	O	O
gene	O	O
expression	O	O
.	O	O

of	O	O

including	O	O
DNA	O	O
methylation	O	O

-	O	O

(	O	O

),	O	O
(	O	O
such	O	O
as	O	O

levels	O	O
.	O	O

exposed	O	O
generation	O	O
.	O	O

¶	O	O
Studies	O	O
in	O	O
which	O	O
environmentally	O	O
induced	O	O
adverse	O	O
phenotype	O	O
(	O	O
s	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
change	O	O
(	O	O

)	O	O
were	O	O

in	O	O
separate	O	O

but	O	O
were	O	O
performed	O	O
within	O	O
the	O	O
same	O	O
experimental	O	O
animals	O	O
.	O	O

Other	O	O
exposures	O	O
of	O	O
environmental	O	O
origin	O	O
that	O	O
have	O	O
been	O	O
extensively	O	O
investigated	O	O
in	O	O
both	O	O
human	O	O
cohorts	O	O
and	O	O
rodent	O	O

include	O	O
stress	O	O

drugs	O	O
,	O	O
maternal	O	O

activation	O	O
/	O	O
infection	O	O
and	O	O
parental	O	O
age	O	O
.	O	O

While	O	O
this	O	O
large	O	O
body	O	O
of	O	O
work	O	O
also	O	O
provides	O	O
some	O	O
comprehensive	B	B
evidence	O	O
for	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
specific	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
of	O	O
,	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicity	O	O
,	O	O
it	O	O
was	O	O
considered	O	O
outside	O	O
the	O	O
scope	O	O
of	O	O
this	O	O
review	O	O
.	O	O

Likewise	O	O
,	O	O
pharmaceutical	O	O
drug	O	O
-	O	O
induced	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicity	O	O
in	O	O
human	O	O
cohorts	O	O
and	O	O
rodent	O	O
models	O	O

been	O	O
reported	O	O
.	O	O

However	O	O
,	O	O
such	O	O
drugs	O	O
are	O	O
not	O	O
environmental	O	O
factors	O	O
and	O	O
so	O	O
were	O	O
not	O	O
considered	O	O
any	O	O
further	O	O
.	O	O

Moreover	O	O
,	O	O
there	O	O
were	O	O
additional	O	O
studies	O	O
that	O	O
have	O	O
investigated	O	O

induced	O	O
epigenetic	O	O

without	O	O
simultaneously	O	O
assessing	O	O
any	O	O

/	O	O
toxicological	O	O
endpoints	O	O
and	O	O
/	O	O
or	O	O
focused	O	O
on	O	O
acute	O	O
exposures	O	O
(	O	O
less	O	O
than	O	O
24	O	O
h	O	O
).	O	O

While	O	O
such	O	O
studies	O	O
are	O	O
more	O	O
difficult	O	O
to	O	O
interpret	O	O
with	O	O
respect	O	O
to	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicity	O	O
(	O	O
and	O	O

were	O	O

this	O	O
review	O	O

useful	O	O

data	O	O
.	O	O

It	O	O
is	O	O
important	O	O
to	O	O
note	O	O
that	O	O
not	O	O
all	O	O
environmentally	O	O

have	O	O
been	O	O

with	O	O

changes	O	O
.	O	O

Indeed	O	O
,	O	O
18	O	O
human	O	O
cohort	O	O
and	O	O
20	O	O
rodent	O	O
studies	O	O
within	O	O
PubMed	O	O
reported	O	O
a	O	O
lack	O	O
of	O	O
epigenetically	O	O
related	O	O
toxicity	O	O
(	O	O
Supplementary	O	O
Table	O	O
4	O	O
).	O	O

studies	O	O
do	O	O
not	O	O
necessarily	O	O
rule	O	O
out	O	O
an	O	O

of	O	O
toxicity	O	O

exclude	B	B
a	O	O
link	O	O
between	O	O
the	O	O
specific	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
,	O	O
exposure	O	O
and	O	O
/	O	O
or	O	O
adverse	O	O
endpoints	O	O
/	O	O
markers	O	O
investigated	O	O
.	O	O

literature	O	O

.	O	O

In	O	O
addition	O	O
,	O	O
concurrent	O	O
in	O	O
vivo	O	O
and	O	O
in	O	O

studies	O	O
have	O	O

into	O	O

Thus	B	B
,	O	O
although	O	O

More	O	O
studies	O	O
that	O	O
incorporate	O	O
some	O	O
form	O	O
of	O	O
inhibition	O	O
/	O	O

/	O	O
cessation	O	O
into	O	O
the	O	O
experimental	O	O
design	O	O
are	O	O
vital	O	O
for	O	O
establishing	O	O
whether	O	O
or	O	O
not	O	O
an	O	O

truly	O	O
represents	O	O
an	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicant	O	O
.	O	O

Although	O	O
potentially	O	O
complex	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
use	O	O
of	O	O
a	O	O
systems	O	O
biology	O	O
approach	O	O

incorporating	O	O

and	O	O

)	O	O
would	O	O
provide	O	O

analysis	O	O
of	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
changes	O	O
and	O	O
associated	O	O
phenotypic	O	O
outcomes	O	O
.	O	O

Subsequent	O	O
identification	O	O
of	O	O
human	O	O
relevant	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
of	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicity	O	O
can	O	O
then	O	O
be	O	O
further	O	O
validated	O	O
as	O	O
appropriate	O	O
in	O	O
smaller	O	O
more	O	O
focused	O	O
studies	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
challenge	O	O
now	O	O
is	O	O
to	O	O
fully	O	O
identify	O	O
and	O	O
investigate	O	O
the	O	O
specific	O	O
functional	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
and	O	O
biological	O	O
pathways	O	O
relevant	O	O
to	O	O
humans	O	O
so	O	O
that	O	O
the	O	O
risk	O	O
(	O	O
s	O	O
)	O	O
of	O	O
environmentally	O	O
induced	O	O
epigenetic	O	O
toxicity	O	O
to	O	O
public	O	O
health	O	O
can	O	O
be	O	O
properly	O	O
assessed	O	O
and	O	O

.	O	O

Research	O	O
considerations	O	O
for	O	O
public	O	O
health	O	O

that	O	O

are	O	O

to	O	O

and	O	O

particularly	O	O
susceptible	O	O

or	O	O
populations	O	O
?	O	O

Adaptive	O	O

change	O	O

change	O	O
offers	O	O
a	O	O
much	O	O
more	O	O
versatile	O	O
,	O	O
reversible	O	O
and	O	O
rapid	O	O
way	O	O
for	O	O

to	O	O
changes	O	O
in	O	O

environment	O	O

with	O	O
genetic	O	O
mutation	O	O
.	O	O

of	O	O

mediated	O	O

of	O	O

pass	O	O
on	O	O

to	O	O
future	O	O

.	O	O

The	O	O

of	O	O

and	O	O
even	O	O

(	O	O

,	O	O

overview	O	O

,	O	O

and	O	O

toxicity	O	O
could	O	O
be	O	O
assessed	O	O
,	O	O
for	O	O
example	O	O
using	O	O
zebrafish	O	O
models	O	O

.	O	O

.	O	O

of	O	O
Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
.	O	O
Background	O	O
Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
promotes	O	O
calcium	O	O
absorption	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
gut	O	O

of	O	O
the	O	O
bone	O	O
.	O	O

is	O	O
also	O	O

for	O	O
bone	O	O
growth	O	O

.	O	O

Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O

bones	O	O
can	O	O
become	O	O
thin	O	O
and	O	O
brittle	O	O
.	O	O

Vitamin	O	O
D	O	O
deficiency	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
linked	O	O
to	O	O
rickets	O	O
in	O	O
children	O	O
and	O	O
osteomalacia	O	O
in	O	O
adults	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
].	O	O

of	O	O

.	O	O

Abstract	O	O

:	O	O

In	O	O

:	O	O

of	O	O
influenza	O	O

[	O	O

Background	O	O
Endocrine	O	O
disrupting	O	O
chemicals	O	O
(	O	O
EDC	O	O
)	O	O
are	O	O
synthetic	O	O
compounds	O	O
found	O	O
in	O	O
many	O	O
consumer	O	O
products	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
–	O	O
3	O	O
]	O	O
that	O	O
alter	O	O
the	O	O
endocrine	O	O
system	O	O
[	O	O
4	O	O
,	O	O
5	O	O
].	O	O

Because	O	O
they	O	O
are	O	O
widely	O	O
distributed	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
environment	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
majority	O	O
of	O	O
pregnant	O	O
women	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
United	O	O
States	O	O
have	O	O
detectable	O	O
levels	O	O
of	O	O
multiple	O	O
EDCs	O	O
in	O	O
their	O	O
blood	O	O
or	O	O
urine	O	O
[	O	O
6	O	O
,	O	O
7	O	O
].	O	O

Among	O	O
EDCs	O	O
,	O	O
broad	O	O
classes	O	O
include	O	O
phthalates	O	O
and	O	O
phenols	O	O
(	O	O
e	O	O
.	O	O
g	O	O
.,	O	O
bisphenol	O	O
A	O	O
[	O	O
BPA	O	O
]),	O	O
perfluoroalkyl	O	O
substances	O	O
(	O	O
PFAS	O	O
),	O	O
polychlorinated	O	O
biphenyls	O	O
(	O	O
PCBs	O	O
),	O	O
polybrominated	O	O
diphenyl	O	O
ethers	O	O
(	O	O
PBDEs	O	O
),	O	O
and	O	O
organochlorine	O	O
pesticides	O	O
(	O	O
OCPs	O	O
).	O	O

Phthalates	O	O
are	O	O
used	O	O
as	O	O
plasticizers	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
,	O	O
4	O	O
,	O	O
5	O	O
,	O	O
8	O	O
]	O	O
and	O	O
also	O	O
found	O	O
in	O	O
personal	O	O
care	O	O
and	O	O
consumer	O	O
products	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
,	O	O
3	O	O
,	O	O
7	O	O
].	O	O

BPA	O	O
is	O	O
added	O	O
to	O	O
many	O	O
plastics	O	O
and	O	O
consumer	O	O
products	O	O
[	O	O
9	O	O
,	O	O
10	O	O
].	O	O

PFAS	O	O
are	O	O
used	O	O
as	O	O
stain	O	O
and	O	O
water	O	O
repellants	O	O
[	O	O
11	O	O
],	O	O
fire	O	O
fighting	O	O
foams	O	O
[	O	O
11	O	O
]	O	O
and	O	O
food	O	O

LASSO	O	O
(	O	O

Bayesian	O	O

linear	O	O
models	O	O
(	O	O
BHLMs	O	O
)	O	O
are	O	O
one	O	O

the	O	O
effect	O	O
of	O	O
multiple	O	O
correlated	O	O
exposures	O	O
[	O	O
32	O	O
].	O	O

BHLM	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
statistical	O	O
method	O	O
belonging	O	O
to	O	O
a	O	O
class	O	O
of	O	O
methods	O	O
known	O	O
as	O	O
shrinkage	O	O
methods	O	O
that	O	O
,	O	O
by	O	O
placing	O	O
constraints	O	O
on	O	O
the	O	O
distribution	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
variables	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
model	O	O
,	O	O
compress	O	O
the	O	O
beta	O	O
coefficients	O	O
toward	O	O
a	O	O
common	O	O
mean	O	O
,	O	O
resulting	O	O
in	O	O
more	O	O
stable	O	O
estimates	O	O
and	O	O
avoiding	O	O
the	O	O
collinearity	O	O
problem	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
also	O	O
reduces	O	O
the	O	O
Type	O	O
I	O	O
error	O	O
(	O	O
false	O	O
positive	O	O
)	O	O
rate	O	O
because	O	O
the	O	O
shrunken	O	O
beta	O	O
coefficients	O	O
are	O	O
closer	O	O
to	O	O
zero	O	O
[	O	O
33	O	O
].	O	O

BHLM	O	O
assumes	O	O
that	O	O
in	O	O
a	O	O
linear	O	O
model	O	O
,	O	O
individual	O	O
regression	O	O
coefficients	O	O
arise	O	O
from	O	O
a	O	O
normal	O	O
distribution	O	O
,	O	O
called	O	O
the	O	O
prior	O	O
distribution	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
prior	O	O
distribution	O	O
depends	O	O
on	O	O
hyperparameters	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
a	O	O
mean	O	O
μβand	O	O
standard	O	O
deviation	O	O
σβ	O	O
,	O	O
which	O	O
are	O	O
informed	O	O
by	O	O
the	O	O
data	O	O
and	O	O
can	O	O
be	O	O
quantified	O	O
when	O	O
fitted	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
data	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
quantity	O	O
μβis	O	O
the	O	O
average	O	O
association	O	O
between	O	O
all	O	O
regression	O	O
coefficients	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
outcome	O	O
,	O	O
whereas	O	O
σβcaptures	O	O
the	O	O
heterogeneity	O	O
of	O	O
effects	O	O
.	O	O

objective	O	O

Outcome	O	O
variables	O	O
The	O	O
outcome	O	O
variable	O	O
was	O	O
birth	O	O
weight	O	O
,	O	O
measured	O	O
in	O	O
grams	O	O
(	O	O
g	O	O
).	O	O

Birth	O	O
weight	O	O
was	O	O
abstracted	O	O
from	O	O
birth	O	O
records	O	O
and	O	O
analyzed	O	O
as	O	O
a	O	O
continuous	O	O
variable	O	O
.	O	O

Biomarkers	O	O
of	O	O
gestational	O	O
EDC	O	O
exposure	O	O
Blood	O	O
and	O	O
urine	O	O
samples	O	O
were	O	O
collected	O	O
from	O	O
participants	O	O
at	O	O
approximately	O	O
16	O	O
weeks	O	O
and	O	O
26	O	O
weeks	O	O
gestation	O	O
.	O	O

We	O	O
used	O	O
sensitive	O	O
and	O	O
specific	O	O
liquid	O	O
or	O	O
gas	O	O
chromatography	O	O
mass	O	O
spectrometry	O	O
[	O	O
34	O	O
]	O	O
to	O	O
measure	O	O
gestational	O	O
EDC	O	O
exposure	O	O
.	O	O

A	O	O
total	O	O
of	O	O
nine	O	O
phthalates	O	O
,	O	O
BPA	O	O
,	O	O
5	O	O
PFAS	O	O
,	O	O
23	O	O

9	O	O

,	O	O

,	O	O
2	O	O

and	O	O
2	O	O

were	O	O
measured	O	O
(	O	O

).	O	O

of	O	O
detection	O	O
(	O	O
LOD	O	O

LOD	O	O
/√	O	O
2	O	O

in	O	O

.	O	O

.	O	O

in	O	O

of	O	O
μg	O	O
/	O	O

serum	O	O
.	O	O

,	O	O

and	O	O

lipid	O	O

of	O	O
ng	O	O
/	O	O

serum	O	O

.	O	O

All	O	O
biomarker	O	O

were	O	O
log10transformed	O	O
and	O	O
treated	O	O
as	O	O
continuous	O	O

.	O	O

and	O	O
BPA	O	O

Introduction	O	O

Visfatin	O	O
,	O	O
a	O	O
new	O	O
52KDa	O	O

(	O	O

that	O	O
it	O	O

called	O	O

Intercellular	O	O

Genetics	O	O
and	O	O

.	O	O

Japanese	O	O

cattle	O	O

has	O	O
the	O	O
highest	O	O
IMF	O	O
content	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
world	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
Korean	O	O
cattle	O	O
(	O	O
also	O	O
called	O	O
Hanwoo	O	O
)	O	O
the	O	O
second	O	O
highest	O	O
.	O	O

Here	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
review	O	O
results	O	O
of	O	O

on	O	O

that	O	O
affect	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

management	O	O
factors	O	O
are	O	O
also	O	O
important	O	O
for	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

Castration	O	O
of	O	O
bulls	O	O
increases	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
most	O	O
cattle	O	O
breeds	O	O
.	O	O

effects	O	O
of	O	O

,	O	O

age	O	O

and	O	O

conditions	O	O
on	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
are	O	O
also	O	O
reviewed	O	O
.	O	O

factors	O	O

,	O	O

of	O	O

,	O	O
glucose	O	O
/	O	O

availability	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
vitamin	O	O
A	O	O
,	O	O

,	O	O
and	O	O

levels	O	O
are	O	O
important	O	O
for	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
through	O	O
developmental	O	O
programming	O	O

metabolic	O	O

is	O	O
a	O	O

proposed	O	O

method	O	O
to	O	O
change	O	O
potential	O	O

.	O	O

of	O	O
fetal	O	O

programming	O	O
to	O	O
increase	O	O
IMF	O	O

of	O	O
progeny	O	O
in	O	O
later	O	O
life	O	O
is	O	O
reviewed	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
coordination	O	O
of	O	O
several	O	O
factors	O	O
affects	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

Thus	B	B
,	O	O
a	O	O
combination	O	O
of	O	O
several	O	O
strategies	O	O
may	O	O
be	O	O
needed	O	O
to	O	O
manipulate	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
,	O	O
depending	O	O
on	O	O
the	O	O
consumer	O	O
’	O	O
s	O	O
beef	O	O
preference	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
particular	O	O
,	O	O
stage	O	O
-	O	O
specific	O	O
feeding	O	O
programs	O	O
with	O	O
concentrate	O	O
-	O	O
based	O	O
diets	O	O
developed	O	O
by	O	O
Japan	O	O
and	O	O
Korea	O	O
are	O	O
described	O	O
in	O	O
this	O	O
article	O	O
.	O	O

INTRODUCTION	O	O
Intramuscular	O	O
fat	O	O
(	O	O
IMF	O	O
)	O	O
deposition	O	O
or	O	O
marbling	O	O
in	O	O
muscle	O	O
including	O	O
the	O	O
longissimus	O	O
thoracis	O	O
et	O	O
lumborum	O	O
,	O	O
infraspinatus	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
biceps	O	O
femoris	O	O
,	O	O
especially	O	O
in	O	O
Korean	O	O
cattle	O	O
(	O	O
also	O	O
called	O	O
Hanwoo	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
Japanese	O	O
Black	O	O
cattle	O	O
,	O	O
is	O	O
one	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
most	O	O
important	O	O
traits	O	O
influencing	O	O
beef	O	O
quality	O	O
and	O	O
palatability	O	O
attributes	O	O
.	O	O

Marbling	O	O
is	O	O
positively	O	O
correlated	O	O
with	O	O
juiciness	O	O
,	O	O
tenderness	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
palatability	O	O
of	O	O
beef	O	O
[	O	O
1	O	O
].	O	O

For	O	O
example	O	O
,	O	O
beef	O	O
with	O	O
higher	O	O
IMF	O	O
produces	O	O
higher	O	O
sensory	O	O
traits	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
tenderness	O	O
,	O	O
juiciness	O	O
,	O	O
flavor	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
overall	O	O
acceptability	O	O
in	O	O
Korean	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
2	O	O
]	O	O
and	O	O
in	O	O
USA	O	O
beef	O	O
samples	O	O
[	O	O
3	O	O
].	O	O

Most	O	O
marbling	O	O
fat	O	O
is	O	O
deposited	O	O
between	O	O
muscle	O	O
fibre	O	O
bundles	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
perimysial	O	O
connective	O	O
tissue	O	O
in	O	O
beef	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
4	O	O
].	O	O

Marbling	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
are	O	O
also	O	O
found	O	O
within	O	O
muscle	O	O
bundles	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
longissimus	O	O
dorsi	O	O
muscle	O	O
(	O	O
LM	O	O
)	O	O
of	O	O
high	O	O
-	O	O
quality	O	O
grade	O	O
Japanese	O	O
Black	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
5	O	O
].	O	O

The	O	O
production	O	O
of	O	O
highly	O	O
marbled	O	O
beef	O	O
in	O	O
Korea	O	O
is	O	O
essential	O	O
to	O	O
compete	O	O
with	O	O
cheap	O	O
imported	O	O
beef	O	O
that	O	O
has	O	O
a	O	O
relatively	O	O
low	O	O
marbling	O	O
score	O	O
(	O	O
MS	O	O
).	O	O

Several	O	O
countries	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
Korea	O	O
,	O	O
Japan	O	O
,	O	O
Australia	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
USA	O	O
,	O	O
have	O	O
considered	O	O
IMF	O	O
content	O	O
as	O	O
important	O	O
to	O	O
beef	O	O
quality	O	O
grade	O	O
(	O	O
QG	O	O
),	O	O
whereas	O	O
European	O	O
countries	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
France	O	O
and	O	O
Germany	O	O
,	O	O
prefer	O	O
leaner	O	O
meat	O	O
(	O	O
less	O	O
IMF	O	O
content	O	O
).	O	O

Understanding	O	O
the	O	O
factors	O	O
affecting	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
responsible	O	O
for	O	O
its	O	O
deposition	O	O
is	O	O
important	O	O
when	O	O
manipulating	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

Our	O	O
laboratory	O	O
has	O	O
studied	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
for	O	O
more	O	O
than	O	O
a	O	O
decade	O	O
to	O	O
understand	O	O
the	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
responsible	O	O
for	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
beef	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
6	O	O
–	O	O
12	O	O
],	O	O
and	O	O
we	O	O
have	O	O
reviewed	O	O
molecular	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
responsible	O	O
for	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
13	O	O
].	O	O

In	O	O
this	O	O
review	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
first	O	O
provide	O	O
an	O	O
overview	O	O
of	O	O
muscle	O	O
and	O	O
fat	O	O
cell	O	O
growth	O	O
in	O	O
ruminants	O	O
.	O	O

Factors	O	O
affecting	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
can	O	O
be	O	O
sub	O	O
-	O	O
categorized	O	O
into	O	O
genetic	O	O
(	O	O
breed	O	O
and	O	O
sex	O	O
differences	O	O
,	O	O
heritability	O	O
),	O	O
management	O	O
(	O	O
weaning	O	O
age	O	O
,	O	O
castration	O	O
,	O	O
slaughter	O	O
weight	O	O
and	O	O
age	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
environment	O	O
),	O	O
and	O	O
nutritional	O	O
factors	O	O
(	O	O
fat	O	O
metabolism	O	O
,	O	O
fat	O	O
digestion	O	O
and	O	O
absorption	O	O
,	O	O
glucose	O	O
/	O	O
starch	O	O
availability	O	O
,	O	O
roughage	O	O
vs	O	O
concentrate	O	O
ratio	O	O
,	O	O
dietary	O	O
energy	O	O
and	O	O
protein	O	O
levels	O	O
,	O	O
vitamins	O	O
A	O	O
,	O	O
D	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
C	O	O
levels	O	O
,	O	O
fetal	O	O
and	O	O
neonatal	O	O
nutritional	O	O
programming	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
stage	O	O
-	O	O
specific	O	O
feeding	O	O
systems	O	O
).	O	O

Here	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
also	O	O
review	O	O
these	O	O
factors	O	O
affecting	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
cattle	O	O
.	O	O

OVERVIEW	O	O
OF	O	O
MUSCLE	O	O
AND	O	O
FAT	O	O
CELL	O	O
GROWTH	O	O
IN	O	O
RUMINANTS	O	O
Skeletal	O	O
muscle	O	O
including	O	O
the	O	O
LM	O	O
mainly	O	O
consists	O	O
of	O	O
skeletal	O	O
muscle	O	O
fibres	O	O
(	O	O
myofibres	O	O
),	O	O
but	O	O
it	O	O
also	O	O
contains	O	O
fat	O	O
cells	O	O
,	O	O
connective	O	O
tissue	O	O
or	O	O
extracellular	O	O
matrix	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
various	O	O
other	O	O
cell	O	O
types	O	O
including	O	O
satellite	O	O
cells	O	O
,	O	O
immune	O	O
cells	O	O
and	O	O
blood	O	O
vessels	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
ratio	O	O
of	O	O
muscle	O	O
to	O	O
fat	O	O
cells	O	O
varies	O	O
depending	O	O
on	O	O
the	O	O
amount	O	O
of	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposited	O	O
.	O	O

Muscle	O	O
and	O	O
fat	O	O
cell	O	O
growth	O	O
typically	O	O
occur	O	O
as	O	O
mass	O	O
increases	O	O
due	O	O
to	O	O
both	O	O
hyperplasia	O	O
(	O	O
increase	O	O
in	O	O
cell	O	O
number	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
hypertrophy	O	O
(	O	O
increase	O	O
in	O	O
cell	O	O
size	O	O
)	O	O
[	O	O
14	O	O
,	O	O
15	O	O
].	O	O

It	O	O
is	O	O
important	O	O
to	O	O
identify	O	O
the	O	O
mechanisms	O	O
responsible	O	O
for	O	O
initial	O	O
muscle	O	O
and	O	O
fat	O	O
cell	O	O
growth	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
developmental	O	O
stage	O	O
of	O	O
cattle	O	O
to	O	O
better	O	O
understand	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
later	O	O
life	O	O
.	O	O

Muscle	O	O
and	O	O
fat	O	O
cell	O	O
development	O	O
are	O	O
dependent	O	O
on	O	O
myogenesis	O	O
(	O	O
muscle	O	O
cell	O	O
formation	O	O
)	O	O
and	O	O
adipogenesis	O	O
(	O	O
fat	O	O
cell	O	O
formation	O	O
),	O	O
respectively	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

The	O	O
process	O	O
of	O	O
skeletal	O	O
muscle	O	O
and	O	O
adipose	O	O
tissue	O	O
development	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
fetal	O	O
stage	O	O
in	O	O
laboratory	O	O
animals	O	O
and	O	O
livestock	O	O
including	O	O
ruminants	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
well	O	O
described	O	O
in	O	O
reviews	O	O
by	O	O
Du	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
–	O	O
18	O	O
].	O	O

Du	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
]	O	O
proposed	O	O
that	O	O
myogenic	O	O
,	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
cells	O	O
are	O	O
derived	O	O
from	O	O
common	O	O
mesenchymal	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
.	O	O

Briefly	O	O
,	O	O
they	O	O
proposed	O	O
that	O	O
mesenchymal	O	O
stem	O	O
cells	O	O
are	O	O
first	O	O
committed	O	O
to	O	O
the	O	O
myogenic	O	O
and	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
–	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
cell	O	O
lineages	O	O
during	O	O
fetal	O	O
muscle	O	O
development	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

Then	O	O
,	O	O
myogenic	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
further	O	O
develop	O	O
into	O	O
muscle	O	O
fibres	O	O
and	O	O
satellite	O	O
cells	O	O
,	O	O
while	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
–	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
develop	O	O
into	O	O
the	O	O
stromal	O	O
–	O	O
vascular	O	O
fraction	O	O
of	O	O
skeletal	O	O
muscle	O	O
,	O	O
where	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
,	O	O
fibroblasts	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
resident	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
–	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
reside	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

Du	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
[	O	O
17	O	O
]	O	O
suggested	O	O
that	O	O
a	O	O
shift	O	O
in	O	O
development	O	O
of	O	O
mesenchymal	O	O
stem	O	O
cells	O	O
from	O	O
myogenesis	O	O
to	O	O
adipogenesis	O	O
may	O	O
increase	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
later	O	O
in	O	O
life	O	O
.	O	O

Adipogenesis	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
comprehensive	O	O
term	O	O
that	O	O
includes	O	O
commitment	O	O
of	O	O
mesenchymal	O	O
stem	O	O
cells	O	O
to	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
,	O	O
determination	O	O
and	O	O
proliferation	O	O
of	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
differentiation	O	O
of	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
into	O	O
mature	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
[	O	O
19	O	O
].	O	O

Adipogenesis	O	O
normally	O	O
begins	O	O
around	O	O
mid	O	O
-	O	O
gestation	O	O
in	O	O
ruminant	O	O
animals	O	O
[	O	O
20	O	O
].	O	O

Differentiation	O	O
of	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
cells	O	O
occurs	O	O
during	O	O
fetal	O	O
and	O	O
postnatal	O	O
stages	O	O
.	O	O

In	O	O
the	O	O
fetal	O	O
stage	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
main	O	O
process	O	O
is	O	O
increasing	O	O
the	O	O
number	O	O
of	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
(	O	O
hyperplasia	O	O
)	O	O
derived	O	O
from	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
–	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
[	O	O
21	O	O
].	O	O

It	O	O
has	O	O
been	O	O
suggested	O	O
that	O	O
adipocyte	O	O
formation	O	O
in	O	O
muscle	O	O
begins	O	O
approximately	O	O
between	O	O
late	O	O
gestation	O	O
and	O	O
250	O	O
d	O	O
after	O	O
birth	O	O
in	O	O
cattle	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

Hyperplasia	O	O
of	O	O
fat	O	O
cells	O	O
mainly	O	O
occurs	O	O
from	O	O
conception	O	O
until	O	O
birth	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
hypertrophy	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
greater	O	O
contributor	O	O
to	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
than	O	O
is	O	O
hyperplasia	O	O
from	O	O
250	O	O
d	O	O
of	O	O
age	O	O
to	O	O
slaughter	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
,	O	O
17	O	O
].	O	O

Both	O	O
hyperplasia	O	O
and	O	O
hypertrophy	O	O
are	O	O
involved	O	O
in	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
(	O	O
Figure	O	O
1	O	O
).	O	O

Therefore	B	B
,	O	O
strategies	O	O
that	O	O
up	O	O
-	O	O
regulate	O	O
both	O	O
hyperplasia	O	O
and	O	O
hypertrophy	O	O
of	O	O
fat	O	O
cells	O	O
are	O	O
effective	O	O
ways	O	O
to	O	O
improve	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
.	O	O

After	O	O
birth	O	O
,	O	O
the	O	O
adipogenic	O	O
–	O	O
fibrogenic	O	O
progenitor	O	O
cells	O	O
re	O	O
main	O	O
on	O	O
some	O	O
parts	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
stromal	O	O
vascular	O	O
cells	O	O
in	O	O
adipose	O	O
tissue	O	O
,	O	O
later	O	O
serving	O	O
as	O	O
precursors	O	O
to	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
and	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
,	O	O
22	O	O
].	O	O

The	O	O
nutritional	O	O
and	O	O
physiological	O	O
condition	O	O
of	O	O
the	O	O
fetus	O	O
and	O	O
the	O	O
early	O	O
postnatal	O	O
stage	O	O
affects	O	O
the	O	O
number	O	O
of	O	O
adipocytes	O	O
in	O	O
adipose	O	O
tissues	O	O
of	O	O
animals	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

Thus	B	B
,	O	O
managing	O	O
maternal	O	O
nutrition	O	O
is	O	O
a	O	O
potentially	O	O
effective	O	O
way	O	O
to	O	O
promote	O	O
adipogenesis	O	O
in	O	O
fetal	O	O
muscle	O	O
[	O	O
16	O	O
].	O	O

Du	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
[	O	O
17	O	O
]	O	O
suggested	O	O
that	O	O
the	O	O
order	O	O
of	O	O
effectiveness	O	O
of	O	O
nutritional	O	O
management	O	O
for	O	O
manipulating	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
is	O	O
fetal	O	O
stage	O	O
>	O	O
neonatal	O	O
stage	O	O
>	O	O
weaning	O	O
stage	O	O
>	O	O
older	O	O
stages	O	O
.	O	O

Harper	O	O
and	O	O
Pethick	O	O
[	O	O
23	O	O
]	O	O
recommended	O	O
that	O	O
producers	O	O
focus	O	O
on	O	O
individuals	O	O
with	O	O
high	O	O
genetic	O	O
capacity	O	O
to	O	O
create	O	O
more	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
within	O	O
animal	O	O
muscle	O	O
.	O	O

Then	O	O
,	O	O
preadipocytes	O	O
can	O	O
differentiate	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
finishing	O	O
stage	O	O
when	O	O
they	O	O
fill	O	O
with	O	O
lipid	O	O
to	O	O
grow	O	O
into	O	O
visible	O	O
marbling	O	O
by	O	O
hypertrophy	O	O
.	O	O

Albrecht	O	O
et	O	O
al	O	O
[	O	O

FACTORS	O	O

early	O	O
finishing	O	O
stages	O	O
instead	O	O
of	O	O
feeding	O	O
concentrate	O	O
and	O	O
roughage	O	O
separately	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
mixed	O	O
ration	O	O
is	O	O
made	O	O
by	O	O
using	O	O
agricultural	O	O
by	O	O
-	O	O
products	O	O
(	O	O
soybean	O	O
curd	O	O
cake	O	O
and	O	O
pomace	O	O
of	O	O
citrus	O	O
,	O	O
apple	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
carrot	O	O
)	O	O
[	O	O
96	O	O
].	O	O

CONCLUSION	O	O
In	O	O
this	O	O
article	O	O
,	O	O
we	O	O
reviewed	O	O
several	O	O
factors	O	O
(	O	O
genetic	O	O
,	O	O
management	O	O
,	O	O
and	O	O
nutritional	O	O
factors	O	O
)	O	O
affecting	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
in	O	O
cattle	O	O
(	O	O
Table	O	O
2	O	O
).	O	O

IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
can	O	O
positively	O	O
affect	O	O
beef	O	O
taste	O	O
including	O	O
tenderness	O	O
and	O	O
flavor	O	O
,	O	O
favoring	O	O
highly	O	O
marbled	O	O
beef	O	O
.	O	O

The	O	O
current	O	O
stage	O	O
-	O	O
specific	O	O
feeding	O	O
program	O	O
for	O	O
producing	O	O
Korean	O	O
cattle	O	O
with	O	O
highly	O	O
marbled	O	O
beef	O	O
relies	O	O
heavily	O	O
on	O	O
feeding	O	O
a	O	O
concentrate	O	O
diet	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
fattening	O	O
period	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
program	O	O
has	O	O
several	O	O
limitations	O	O
:	O	O
the	O	O
high	O	O
proportion	O	O
of	O	O
concentrate	O	O
in	O	O
the	O	O
diet	O	O
and	O	O
long	O	O
fattening	O	O
period	O	O
(>	O	O
30	O	O
months	O	O
,	O	O
especially	O	O
in	O	O
Korean	O	O

and	O	O
Japanese	O	O

may	O	O
increase	O	O
feed	O	O
costs	O	O
.	O	O

Excess	O	O
energy	O	O
supplied	O	O
to	O	O
mature	O	O
animals	O	O
during	O	O
the	O	O
late	O	O
fattening	O	O
period	O	O
may	O	O
significantly	O	O
decrease	O	O
feed	O	O
efficiency	O	O
.	O	O

This	O	O
may	O	O
decrease	O	O
digestibility	O	O
of	O	O
feed	O	O
,	O	O
increase	O	O
animal	O	O
feed	O	O
waste	O	O

and	O	O
eventually	O	O
raise	O	O
issues	O	O
of	O	O
animal	O	O
industry	O	O

.	O	O

Current	O	O
methods	O	O
to	O	O
increase	O	O
IMF	O	O
deposition	O	O
are	O	O
generally	B	B
limited	O	O
to	O	O

overall	O	O
body	O	O
fat	O	O
deposition	O	O
,	O	O
including	O	O
inedible	O	O
fat	O	O
.	O	O

(	O	O
